summary: This document is an email chain from July 25, 2019, discussing the status of obtaining investigative files and reports related to an incident involving Jeffrey Epstein at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) in New York. The emails reveal internal coordination among prosecutors and investigators following reports that Epstein was found in his cell with a noose around his neck on the morning of July 24, 2019, and concerns about the reliability of information and the speed of obtaining official documents.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The subject of the email chain; reported to have been found in his cell with a noose around his neck and placed on suicide watch/observation.

persons.name: Tartaglione
persons.context: Mentioned as part of a legal team ("Epstein and Tartaglione teams") that should receive reviewed files, indicating another case or co-defendant.

connections.description: Both are referenced as having legal teams that should receive reviewed investigative files from the MCC incident, suggesting a procedural connection in the legal process.

events.title: Epstein Found with Noose in Cell
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein was found in his cell at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) New York at 0127 hours in a fetal position with a noose around his neck. He was escorted to medical, assessed, initially placed on suicide watch, and subsequently downgraded to suicide observation.

events.title: Internal DOJ Coordination for MCC Files
events.description: Email discussions among prosecutors and investigators about obtaining official reports from the MCC regarding the Epstein incident, including strategies to expedite the process through an AUSA investigator with good relationships at MCC.

keyFacts: Jeffrey Epstein was found in his cell at MCC New York on July 24, 2019, at 0127 hours with a noose around his neck.
Initial reports from the SHU Lieutenant mentioned only redness on Epstein's neck, but supplemental reports from responding officers stated Epstein had something around his neck.
Epstein was initially placed on suicide watch after the incident but was subsequently downgraded to suicide observation.
Epstein's cell mate reported being threatened by Epstein.
The email chain reveals internal DOJ concerns about obtaining reliable and timely official reports from the Bureau of Prisons regarding the incident.
